Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA) to require employers to provide employees with up to six days, or up to 48 hours, of earned paid sick leave.
Employers with at least 16 employees must begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must begin providing earned paid sick leave effective January 1, 2022.
Effective immediately, the HFWA requires that employers, regardless of size, comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act in the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which stays in effect until December 31, 2020. The Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act provides up to 80 hours of sick leave for COVID-19-related reasons. The HFWA does not require employers to comply with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA, which provides 12 weeks of pay to care for children whose school or place of care is closed, or childcare provider is unavailable, because of COVID-19-related reasons.
Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics will have the authority to enforce the requirements of the HFWA. The Division will be providing rules regarding compensation and accrual of paid sick leave under the HFWA.
Employee Eligibility
Employees immediately begin to accrue paid sick leave upon hire and may use sick leave as soon as it is accrued.
How Employees Accrue Paid Sick Leave
Each employee earns at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours the employee works, up to 48 hours of paid sick leave per year, unless the employer selects a higher limit.
An employer may satisfy the accrual requirements of the HFWA by providing the employee with an amount of paid sick leave that meets or exceeds the requirements of the HFWA at the beginning of the year.
Exempt employees who work less than a 40-hour workweek accrue paid sick leave based on the number of hours that comprise the employee’s normal workweek.
Reasons for Taking Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for the following reasons:
The employee:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition that prevents the employee from working;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee needs to care for a family member who:
(i) Has a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition;
(ii) Needs to obtain a medical diagnosis, care, or treatment of a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; or
(iii) Needs to obtain preventive medical care.
The employee or the employee’s family member has been the victim of domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment and the use of leave is to:
(i) Seek medical attention for the employee or the employee’s family member to recover from a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition caused by the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
(ii) Obtain services from a victim services organization;
(iii) Obtain mental health or other counseling;
(iv) Seek relocation due to the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment; or
(v) Seek legal services, including preparation for or participation in a civil or criminal proceeding relating to or resulting from the domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment;
Due to a public health emergency, a public official has ordered closure of:
(i) The employee’s place of business; or
(ii) The school or place of care of the employee’s child and the employee needs to be absent from work to care for the employee’s child.
Taking Paid Sick Leave
Employees must take paid sick leave in one-hour increments, unless the employer permits employees to take leave in smaller increments. Employers may loan paid sick leave to an employee who has not yet accrued it.
Employers may not require, as a condition of taking paid sick leave, that the employee search for and find a replacement worker to cover the employee’s paid sick leave.
Requests for accrued paid sick leave must be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any other means acceptable to the employer. When possible, the employee must include the expected duration of the absence. An employer may adopt a written policy that contains reasonable procedures for the employee to provide notice when the use of paid sick leave taken under the HFWA is foreseeable; however, an employer cannot deny paid sick leave to the employee based on noncompliance with such a policy. When the leave is foreseeable, employees should make a good faith effort to provide notice to the employer and make a reasonable effort to schedule paid sick leave in a manner that does not unduly disrupt business operations.
Carry Over of Accrued Paid Sick Leave
Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave to the following year; however, employers can limit the amount of leave an employee may take in any year to 48 hours.
Paid Sick Leave at Separation
The HFWA does not create an obligation for employers to pay out unused, accrued paid sick leave at separation, regardless of the reason for separation.
However, an individual may recover paid sick leave as a remedy for a retaliatory personnel action that prevented the individual from using paid sick leave.
Additionally, if an employer rehires a separated employee within six months of that employee’s separation, the employer must reinstate any unused, accrued paid sick leave the employee had during the employee’s previous employment.
Paid Sick Leave and Public Health Emergencies (e.g., COVID-19)
In addition to the paid sick leave accrued as described above, employees are entitled to a one-time grant of leave in the event of a “public health emergency.”
A public health emergency is defined as an act of bioterrorism, a pandemic influenza, or an epidemic caused by a novel and highly fatal infectious act, for which: (1) a disaster emergency is declared by the governor; or (2) an emergency is declared by a federal, state, or local public health agency; or (3) a highly infectious illness or agent with epidemic or pandemic potential for which a disaster emergency is declared by the governor.
To ensure employees may take paid sick leave for the reasons below, employers must supplement employees’ accrued paid sick leave as necessary (at least 80 hours for employees who work at least 40 hours a week; for employees who work fewer than 40 hours a week, the amount of time the employee is scheduled to work or the average of what the employee actually works in a 14-day period, whichever is greater):
An employee’s need to:
(i) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(ii) Self-isolate and care for oneself because the employee is experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iii) Seek or obtain medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(iv) Seek preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(v) Care for a family member who:
(a) Is self-isolating after being diagnosed with a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(b) Is self-isolating due to experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
(c) Needs medical diagnosis, care, or treatment if experiencing symptoms of a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency; or
(d) Is seeking preventive care concerning a communicable illness that is the cause of a public health emergency;
Or if:
(i) A local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the employee’s place of employment is located or the employee’s employer determines that the employee’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the employee’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the employee is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the employee has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
Or to:
(ii) Care for a family member after a local, state, or federal public official or health authority having jurisdiction over the location in which the family member’s place of employment is located or the family member’s employer determines that the family member’s presence on the job or in the community would jeopardize the health of others because of the family member’s exposure to the communicable illness or because the family member is exhibiting symptoms of the communicable illness, regardless of whether the family member has been diagnosed with the communicable illness;
(iii) Care for a child or other family member when the individual’s child care provider is unavailable due to a public health emergency, or if the child’s or family member’s school or place of care has been closed by a local, state, or federal public official or at the discretion of the school or place of care due to a public health emergency, including if a school or place of care is physically closed but providing instruction remotely;
Or due to:
(iv) An employee’s inability to work because the employee has a health condition that may increase susceptibility to or risk of a communicable illness that is the cause of the public health emergency.
Employers may count an employee’s unused, accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave. Employers may not require documentation for taking this leave and employees may use this leave up until four weeks after the official termination or suspension of the public health emergency.
Recordkeeping
Employers must retain records for each employee for a two-year period, documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and paid sick leave used.
Anti-Retaliation
The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who take this leave, providing an avenue of relief if employees feel their employer has taken any adverse action against them.
Violations of the HFWA includes compensating an employee until the employee is reinstated or, if reinstatement is not feasible, for a reasonable period.
An employer who willfully retaliates against an employee will be subject to a civil fine of up to $100 for each separate violation.
Aggrieved individuals also may file a civil action after submitting a complaint to the Division or after making a written demand for compensation or other relief to the employer. An employer has 14 days to respond after receiving a notice from the Division that a complaint has been filed with it or a written demand from the aggrieved person.
Notice to Employees
Employers must notify its employees, in writing, that they are entitled to paid sick leave, in accordance with the rules that will be promulgated by the Division. Employers must immediately post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute to employees the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A. Employers also must provide notices and posters in any language that is the first language spoken by at least five percent of its workforce.
Additional posters and notices will be made available to employers to comply with these notice requirements for 2021.
Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated
Colorado’s HELP Rules are no longer in effect. The HELP Rules were adopted and effective on March 11, 2020, and were to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency declared by the Governor up 120 days, whichever is greater. The Division terminated the requirements of the HELP Rules on July 14, the day before the HFWA went into effect.
The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (up to a maximum of 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees with flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who are being tested for COVID-19 or who are under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to a risk of having COVID-19.
***
Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including the poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to language in employee handbooks, implementation strategies, or any other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.

Colorado has enacted the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (SB20-205) (HFWA), which requires employers to provide employees with up to six days (48 hours) of earned paid sick leave annually.

- **Employer Applicability and Effective Dates:**  
  Employers with 16 or more employees were required to begin providing earned paid sick leave on January 1, 2021. All employers, regardless of size, must comply effective January 1, 2022.

- **Federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act Compliance:**  
  Until December 31, 2020, employers of all sizes were required to comply with the federal Emergency Paid Sick Leave Act under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), which provided up to 80 hours of COVID-19-related paid sick leave. The HFWA does not require compliance with the Emergency Family and Medical Leave Expansion Act of the FFCRA.

- **Enforcement:**  
  Colorado’s Division of Labor Standards and Statistics enforces the HFWA and issues rules regarding paid sick leave compensation and accrual.

### Employee Eligibility and Accrual  
- Employees begin accruing paid sick leave immediately upon hire and may use leave as soon as it is accrued.  
- Employees earn at least one hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 48 hours per year, unless the employer sets a higher limit.  
- Employers may provide the full annual amount of paid sick leave at the start of the year to satisfy accrual requirements.  
- Exempt employees working less than 40 hours per week accrue leave based on their normal workweek hours.

### Permissible Reasons for Using Paid Sick Leave  
Employees may use accrued paid sick leave for:  
- Their own mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; obtaining medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Caring for a family member with a mental or physical illness, injury, or health condition; obtaining medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care.  
- Addressing domestic abuse, sexual assault, or harassment for themselves or a family member, including:  
  - Seeking medical attention;  
  - Obtaining services from victim organizations;  
  - Receiving mental health or counseling services;  
  - Seeking relocation;  
  - Pursuing legal services related to the abuse, assault, or harassment.  
- Absences due to public health emergencies, including:  
  - Closure of the employee’s workplace;  
  - Closure of the employee’s child’s school or place of care requiring the employee to care for the child.

**2023 Amendments:**  
The HFWA was amended in 2023 to expand permissible leave reasons to explicitly include reproductive health care (including pregnancy-related conditions and care) and broaden domestic violence-related leave provisions. Employers should update policies accordingly.

### Use and Scheduling of Paid Sick Leave  
- Leave must be taken in one-hour increments unless the employer allows smaller increments.  
- Employers may loan paid sick leave to employees who have not yet accrued it.  
- Employers cannot require employees to find replacement workers as a condition of taking leave.  
- Leave requests may be made orally, in writing, electronically, or by any employer-accepted method.  
- Employers may adopt reasonable written notice policies for foreseeable leave but cannot deny leave for noncompliance. Employees should provide good faith notice and attempt to schedule leave to minimize business disruption.

### Carryover and Separation  
- Employees may carry over up to 48 hours of unused paid sick leave annually, but employers may cap leave usage at 48 hours per year.  
- Employers are not required to pay out unused sick leave upon separation.  
- If an employee is rehired within six months, the employer must reinstate unused accrued paid sick leave from prior employment.  
- Paid sick leave may be recovered as a remedy for retaliatory personnel actions preventing leave use.

### Supplemental Leave for Public Health Emergencies  
- Employees are entitled to a one-time supplemental leave grant during a declared public health emergency (e.g., pandemic, epidemic, bioterrorism).  
- Supplemental leave must be at least 80 hours for full-time employees or prorated for part-time employees based on scheduled or average hours worked over 14 days.  
- Supplemental leave covers:  
  - Self-isolation or care due to diagnosis or symptoms of a communicable illness causing the emergency;  
  - Seeking medical diagnosis, care, treatment, or preventive care related to the illness;  
  - Caring for family members with similar conditions or exposures;  
  - Absences due to public official orders restricting presence at work or in the community;  
  - Caring for children or family members when childcare or schools are closed or unavailable due to the emergency;  
  - Employee’s inability to work due to a health condition increasing susceptibility to the illness.  
- Employers may count unused accrued paid time off toward this supplemental leave.  
- Documentation cannot be required for this leave, and it may be used up to four weeks after the public health emergency ends.

### Recordkeeping Requirements  
Employers must retain records for two years documenting hours worked, paid sick leave accrued, and leave used for each employee.

### Anti-Retaliation Protections  
- The HFWA prohibits retaliation against employees who use paid sick leave.  
- Remedies for violations include compensation until reinstatement or for a reasonable period if reinstatement is not feasible.  
- Willful retaliation may result in civil fines up to $100 per violation.  
- Employees may file complaints with the Division or pursue civil actions after providing written demand to the employer. Employers have 14 days to respond to such notices.

### Employee Notice and Posting Requirements  
- Employers must provide written notice to employees about their paid sick leave rights per Division rules.  
- Employers must post the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster and distribute the Division’s Interpretive Notice & Formal Opinion #6A.  
- Notices and posters must be provided in any language spoken as a first language by at least 5% of the workforce.  
- Additional posters and notices will be made available to assist employers in meeting 2021 notice requirements.

In addition to these notices, Colorado employers are required to post specific labor law posters in the workplace to comply with state and federal regulations. These posters inform employees of their rights under laws such as the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), minimum wage, discrimination protections, and OSHA requirements. Colorado labor law posters are available for purchase from authorized vendors in laminated formats that combine all mandatory state and federal notices into a single poster for convenience and compliance assurance. Purchasing these posters helps employers meet posting obligations, avoid fines, and stay current with legal updates through subscription services or replacement plans. Employers should prominently display these posters in accessible workplace locations and update them as laws change.

### Employee Handbook Templates and Compliance Resources  
To assist with HFWA compliance, employers can utilize employee handbook templates tailored to Colorado labor laws. These templates provide clear policies on paid sick leave accrual, usage, and employee rights, helping employers maintain compliance and reduce legal risks. Templates and services are available for purchase from reputable providers, offering customizable options and updates aligned with recent 2023 amendments. Additionally, legal compliance tools and software platforms can help employers manage paid sick leave tracking, recordkeeping, and notification requirements efficiently. Integrating these resources within employee handbooks and workplace policies supports consistent application of HFWA provisions and simplifies adherence to evolving employment laws.

### 2023 Employment Law Updates Affecting Colorado Employers  
Employers should also be aware of related 2023 amendments impacting Colorado employment law, including updates to the Equal Pay for Equal Work Act that affect job postings and pay transparency requirements. Furthermore, the Job Application Fairness Act, effective in 2024, prohibits age-related questions on job applications and introduces other protections for small businesses. Practical compliance guidance and legal support resources are available to help employers navigate these changes alongside HFWA obligations.  

### Employee Handbook Templates and Compliance Resources  
To assist employers in complying with the Healthy Families and Workplaces Act (HFWA), many choose to utilize employee handbook templates that incorporate the required paid sick leave policies and notices. These templates help ensure that employer policies align with HFWA requirements, reduce legal risks, and streamline communication with employees.  
Templates are available for purchase from various reputable legal and HR service providers, including Jackson Lewis, SHRM, and other specialized vendors. Examples include comprehensive handbook templates that cover paid sick leave accrual, usage, carryover, anti-retaliation provisions, and public health emergency leave policies. Using these templates can simplify the process of updating employee handbooks to reflect HFWA mandates and help employers maintain consistent and compliant workplace policies.  
Employers should review and customize any purchased templates to fit their specific workplace needs and consult with legal counsel to ensure full compliance with the HFWA and related regulations.  

In addition to handbook templates, employers may benefit from legal compliance tools and software platforms designed to help manage Colorado paid sick leave requirements efficiently. These tools often include features such as automated accrual tracking, leave request management, recordkeeping, and real-time updates on legislative changes. Examples of providers offering such solutions include Workday, BambooHR, and Zenefits, which integrate paid sick leave compliance into broader HR management systems. Utilizing these platforms can reduce administrative burdens, minimize errors, and ensure timely adherence to HFWA mandates and related employment laws. Employers are encouraged to evaluate these tools based on their organizational size, complexity, and specific compliance needs.  

Employers must also ensure compliance with Colorado’s posting requirements by displaying the appropriate labor law compliance posters in the workplace. These posters include the Colorado Workplace Public Health Rights Poster, the HFWA notice, and other mandatory state and federal labor law posters. Posters can be purchased from reputable vendors such as the Colorado Department of Labor and Employment, PosterCompliance.com, and LaborLawCenter.com. Employers may choose to buy individual state and federal posters or opt for all-in-one poster kits that combine all required postings. Many providers offer subscription services that automatically send updated posters when laws change, helping employers avoid fines for non-compliance. Posting these notices in a conspicuous location accessible to all employees is critical to meeting state law requirements and maintaining compliance with the HFWA and other labor regulations.  

### Colorado Health Emergency Leave with Pay (HELP) Rules Terminated  
Colorado’s HELP Rules, effective March 11, 2020, and intended to remain in effect for 30 days or the duration of the state of disaster emergency (up to 120 days), were terminated by the Division on July 14, 2020, the day before the HFWA went into effect.  

The HELP Rules required employers to provide up to two weeks (maximum 80 hours) of paid sick leave at two-thirds of the employee’s regular rate of pay to employees exhibiting flu-like or respiratory illness symptoms who were being tested for COVID-19 or were under instruction from a healthcare provider or authorized government official to quarantine or isolate due to COVID-19 risk.  

---

### Related 2023 Employment Law Updates Affecting Colorado Employers  

In addition to the 2023 HFWA amendments, several other significant employment law changes took effect in Colorado in 2023 that impact small businesses and employers:  

- **Equal Pay for Equal Work Act Amendments (2023):** These amendments enhance pay transparency requirements and impose stricter rules on job postings, including prohibiting employers from asking about salary history and requiring disclosure of pay ranges in job advertisements. Employers should update job postings and compensation policies accordingly.  

- **Job Application Fairness Act (Effective 2024):** This new law prohibits employers from asking applicants about their age or date of birth on job applications, aiming to reduce age discrimination. Employers should revise application forms and hiring procedures to comply.  

- **Other Small Business Employment Law Changes:** Various updates include expanded protections against discrimination, updated wage and hour rules, and new requirements for workplace postings and notices.  

Employers, especially small businesses, are encouraged to review these changes carefully and seek guidance to ensure compliance. Practical steps include updating employee handbooks, training HR personnel, revising job application and posting templates, and maintaining clear communication with employees about their rights under these laws.  

Jackson Lewis attorneys are available to assist employers in their compliance efforts. If you have questions about the HFWA, including poster and employee notice requirements, revisions to handbook language, implementation strategies, or other workplace issues, please contact the Jackson Lewis attorney with whom you regularly work.
